dialogues.speaker: TOMMY "BIRDMAN" ROWAN
dialogues.text: 28. Blond and stocky. Former coolest kid in high school. At one time, he commanded the night brigade. Now he plows He rolls with

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: 29. Apple-pie face. The thick Wade Boggs moustache does n good - Kev still looks 10 years younger than he really is Kev is Copperfield to Birdman’s J. Steerforth... Kev hops from the truck and begins to shovel the walk, as Birdman plows the driveway of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful house. Christmas lights still dangle... Birdm Plows with great care... He leaves no crumbs... He studie the windows of the Tudor, looking for signs of life... They finish quickly... Kev hops back into the truck. He picks up a clipboard, crosses off one last name.

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: That’s it -- Birdman nods. He looks back at the house. Sighs, Puts the truck in reverse. As it skirts the end of the driveway, a OUTSIDE LIGHT flicks on... A hint of a smile crosses Birdman’s face. It is not lost Kev, who snorts...

dialogues.speaker: KEV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Aw, shit -- The Tudor's front door OPENS... A LITTLE GIRL, KRISTEN, 3 bundled up good, trudges out of the house, carrying two pewter MUGS of coffee... She walks precariously, balancing the mugs, negotiating way across Kev’s freshly-cleared walkway... Birdman opens the truck door... Leans down to the little and takes the coffees...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Kristen. How are you tonight? Kristen merely stares at him. Her expression an admixture terror and confusion... Birdman hands Kev a mug. Kev slurps at it... Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: No ‘buca -- Birdman doesn’t hear him. For the front door has opened again. To Kristen’s mother. Birdman watches as

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN SMALLS
dialogues.text: 28, in ski parka, leggings and Timberlands, walks to the truck. Blonde hair pp. Black eyes, Darian has about her t melancholy air of a Thomas Hardy heroine...

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Hey -- Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Darian? No Zambuca this time -- ?

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: It’s 5:00 in the morning --

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: ‘Zat make it too late or too early?

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should lay off it a bit, Kev. Your nose gets any redder, you could guide my sleigh tonight -- Kev stares at her blankly... She turns to Birdman:

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You guys done for the night?

dialogues.speaker: , BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big storm --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Beat. Kristen tugs at her mother’s leg...

dialogues.speaker: KRIS'
dialogues.text: I'm coooooldddd -- !

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: Okay, baby... She picks up her daughter. Looks at Birdman. Forces a smi The shit between them is so palpable it could wear clothe

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (re: the mugs) I didn’t have Styrofoam... ‘

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I'll get ‘em back to you -- Darian nods. Birdman nods. Kev rolis his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Kev --

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: DARIAN
dialogues.text: {to Birdman) Bye -- Birdman nods again. Watches her walk back to the house, carrying Jodi.” He starts up the truck. Looks at Kev, who giving him the ugly eyeball...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: The thing with the Styrofoam really creases me...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: It's the fifth storm of the season - you'd think she’d get herself a nice sleeve of Styrofoam cups. $1.99 at your local Shop ‘N Save...  Nothing from Birdman. He drives. KEV (CONT.) . How ‘bout J return the mugs this time?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you shut your hole? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Chick’s married, Birdie. Birdman drives.

dialogues.speaker: KEV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: It's all bad -- The truck drives off into the snow...

dialogues.speaker: ROLL CREDITS
dialogues.text: to the Gin Blossoms nifty ditty "Lost Horizons" ("Drink enough of anything/To make this world look new again... " we follow the truck through the stormy streets of The Rid -- passing other plows, other sanders, other hearty MEN shoveling out driveways and roads, so the day-workers won be inconvenienced in their morning commute... As our credit sequence rolis to a close, we find ourselve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The racks are filled with a colorful diorama of donuts an crullers. The place is fairly crowded with PLOWERS and SANDERS and other members of the town’s snow removal team In one booth, opposite two town COPS, sits

dialogues.speaker: GINA BARRISANO, 30,
dialogues.text: A heavy-set Italian girl tearing the crown off of her oat-bran muffin, washing it down with an iced coffee...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: .-. all I’m saying is: the odds of the jellied side of the toast falling face down are proportional to the cost of the carpet... She sees Birdman and Kev enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. Look who’s here: Captain Kangaroo and his faithful sidekick, Mr. Green Jeans...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Nice to see you too, Gina -- They go to a nearby table... At the rear of the joint, a phone RINGS ON in the ear of

dialogues.speaker: PAUL KLAPMAN
dialogues.text: 29, Winston cigarette, short black hair, layers of therma flannel, denim. He is at the pay phone. He looks exhauste sipping coffee from an enormous Excellent Donuts cup... He slams down the phone. Goes back to a booth, where Bird and Kev are working on a bag of donut holes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s not home --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s banging that gu

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: She’s sleeping --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I/1l bet you twenty bucks she’s banging that guy --

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: What a ridiculous bet --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Why?

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Either way - you lose. If you win, she’s bangin’. So you lose. If you lose, you lose 20 bucks. So you lose. A lose-lose bet is not a bet to make ~~

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I hate her --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You really think she’s with this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do --

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: The meat-cutter?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fuckin’ meat~cutter. What kind of future is that? The guy cuts meat --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You plow snow...

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: At least meat - you can eat. Paul looks at Kev. Kev shrugs. Paul to Birdman:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why you gotta always bring him around?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: He's a hell of a shoveller -- Paul drains his coffee. Gets to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm outta here. JI‘1ll see you at home -- He puts on his hat, his gloves...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN -
dialogues.text: Don’t go by Jan’s -- -

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You gonna sand my lots -- ?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Don’t go by there --~-

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not goin’ by there -- Paul leaves them...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: He's goin’ by there --

dialogues.speaker: . KEV
dialogues.text: Money in the bank -- Paul passes the booth with Gina and the cops...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You seen Jan around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t eat red meat -- Paul shakes his head and leaves the donut shoppe... Gina shrugs to the cops...

dialogues.speaker: GINA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nice guy but not too bright. He could hide his own Easter eggs, know what I mean... ? cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A COMPACT DISC
dialogues.text: inserted into an ultra-pimped-out CAR STEREO CD receiver a 6/5 channel amp, optimized for enclosures... Kiss’ "Do You Love Me" off the DESTROYER disc, CRANKS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few towns over. Paul is in his '84 Ford F-150 with a 7 foot Myers plow - "KLAPMAN LANDSCAPE" stencilled on the s He chain-smokes Winstons... Staring at the duplex... His mixed-breed MUTT - ELLE MACPHERSON - is with him... The Kiss tune WAILS through the four hi-fi plate system speakers and 10" component subwoofer... Paul lowers the plow. Begins to move the snow. MOVE IT IN the DRIVEWAY of the duplex. A few plow-fuls and the drive is a five-foot high inpenetrable WALL OF SNOW... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: TWO FAT CHILDREN
dialogues.text: cherubic, faces smeared with chocolate, goggle down at us The GIRL is 5, the BOY is 3... INT. BIRDMAN AND PAUL’S HOUSE - DAY They rent one half of this decent-sized two-family. Birdman is sprawled out on the couch. The two children st over him... He wakes with a terrified YOWL --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: desus -- ! The children chortle evil, little chortles. Their father,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29, walks around the small living room, picking up beer c raising the blinds... Sun, reflected off all that snow, c sizzling through the windows. Mo is big, doughy, pale. Dagwood Bumstead eyes and a guileless Irish demeanor...

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Rise and shine, Birdman. Rise and shine-

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Eleven-thirty on a beautiful Sunday morning. The storm has passed, the sun is high in the sky --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Mo, your kids are so goddamn ugly, you should need a permit just to take ‘em out in public -- Mo hands Birdman a MUG of coffee. Birdman winces as he notices the "KRISTEN" printed on the side of the mug.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You're jealous. The kids, SHANNON and MICHAEL JR. parade around the livin room, gnawing on oversized Sugar Daddys...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Look at ‘em. They’re like little trolls. They belong under a bridge...

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Willie’s coming in today...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: The reunion. I’m going to get him at 1:00. You wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I gotta work -- Paul comes down the stairs, still mossy with sleep... He Mo’s kids. Screams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you gotta bring them ugly kids around here, Mo? Damn --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: It's like being really hung over and getting a whiff of whiskey, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: _ PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, it is --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Willie’s coming in at 1:00 -- Paul nods. Gets coffee. He makes a face at Mo’s kids... They make faces back. Paul grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: {to Birdman) You sand my lots -- ? '

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. You go by Jan’s -- ?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Of course -- The back door opens and Birdman’s girlfriend, SHARON, ent carrying a bag of groceries. She is 27 and pretty, if too skinny. She immediately sets to clucking over Mo’s kids -

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Oh, golly! Look at you! Look at you guys! You are soooo adorable -- Sharon gets a towel and wipes the goo off the kids’ faces Mo shoots Paul and Birdman a gloating grin...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, please, Sharon. They’re like the poster children for the Pro Choice movement -~- Paul smears cream cheese on a bagel -- Sharon kisses Birdman, who has retreated to his couch, a hockey game on the tube...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Good night?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: We did all right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prought you some stuff. Sandwich meat, cookies, juice...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Maybe you'll eat some -- She glares at him. Goes to the kitchen to unpack the bund

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get Willie. Wanna go, Paui?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nah. I got shit to do -- Paul flops down on the other couch with his bagel...

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You guys are great friends...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Willie's coming home?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Is he still seeing that girl?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I dunno. Come on, kids. Let’s go fetch Uncle Willie at the train station --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t bring those fuckin’ kids around anymore ~~

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tommy -- !

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Watch your language --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I'm serious, Mo --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah ~-

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tommy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They give me nightmares --~ Sharon shakes her head. Mo hustles his kids out the back.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Don't get mad, Shar. These guys, deep in their souls, they yearn for what I got. They want kids so bad it hurts them... ey just don’t know it yet... Paul WHIPS HIS BAGEL at Mo’s head. It misses and sticks t the yall in cream cheese adhesion... Mo chuckles and leav the house...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You guys are so vile --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Big idiot should be neutered -- .

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Big idiot should be Xeroxed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo drives his Bronco towards the train platform, which is empty, save for WILLIE CONWAY, 29. Long hair, long coat. Willie paces between his suitcases. Mo gets out of the car, comes around. Mo tosses the bags the trunk of the car. Willie gets in the front.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You remember Shannon and Michael dr.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hi, kids! Wow, Mo, they’re... cute.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Good to be back?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I've been back exactly 11 minutes...

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You still seeing that chick?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That depends on what you mean by "seeing."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still living at her place?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: We're living together. Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You're not engaged?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: It's been, what, a year?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Eleven months. Going together for eleven months. Living together for six.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: She doesn’t put any pressure on you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That depends on what you mean by "pressure."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo pulls up in front of the small ranch house. Snow banks everywhere give the neighborhood a surreal quality... Willie takes his bags from the back... -

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride, man --~

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: We'll check you out, soon. You'll come over for brunch. Lisa’ll make waffles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Absolutely -- Willie eyes his house, a little uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You okay with this?

dialogues.speaker: _ WILLIE
dialogues.text: Fine. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice... Mo points. Willie looks next door. To where his neighbor a 13-year-old GIRL, is making an anatomically-correct SNO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those‘d be true snow balls ~- Willie nods and heads for the house. He and the girl exchange a look as he goes. Mo climbs back into his car.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Okay, kids. Who wants ice cream? The kids squeal. And Mo drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie enters, kicking the snow from his boots. The house plain, drab, a woman’s touch long absent. A baby grand PI is the living room’s only flourish... His father, PETE CONWAY, 62, carries the Sunday paper and weight of the world...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hello, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONWAY
dialogues.text: When’d you get in?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Just now. Mo picked me up.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONWAY
dialogues.text: Lot a bags. Staying long?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONWAY
dialogues.text: There’s some golf on. Would you like to watch some golf?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: PETE CONWAY
dialogues.text: Put your stuff away. Come down and watch some golf -- Willie nods. His father stocking-feet-shuffles to the TV room. Willie goes upstairs. INT. WILLIE’S BEDROOM A boy’s room. Old, yellowing posters of The Who, The Bost Red Sox, Larry Bird. A stack of record albums. A stack of MAD magazines... Willie’s bed seems very small.. . A KNOCK on the opened door. Willie’s brother, DOUGIE, 24 there, in underwear and t-shirt... Tall, gangly, thick bl hair tufting out from under a dirty Boston Bruins cap...

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: Yo, man. What up?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Doug. You just getting up?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wild night. Got wrecked. Dougie sees Willie’s bags --

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You gonna be home long -- ?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno. We’ll see -- . Dougie nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: See Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're gonna watch some golf --

dialogues.speaker: DOUGTE
dialogues.text: You missed a helluva storm --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: When did the Ryans move out?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: The Ryans? I dunno. Last year?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Who moved in?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: They got a kid --

dialogues.speaker: DOUGIE
dialogues.text: Do they? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I think they do. Dougie nods. Willie nods. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta take a shit -- He leaves. Willie lies back on his bed. Stares at the ceiling. Be it ever so humble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s just starting to snow. Paul waits outside in his tru Willie comes out of the house, climbs into the truck, nex the dog --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s up, bad boy? You remember Elle MacPherson -- ?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. How you doing, man -- ?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Jan's banging some meat-cutter. The truck drives off. INT. PAUL’S TRUCK - MOVING - NIGHT Paul slides a disc into the deck. Boston. "Piece of Mind" off the first album...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We been having some troubles. Things started to get crazy about a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I heard you got The Ultimatum --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like fuck that, okay? What right does she have to give me The Ultimatum?

dialogues.speaker: __. WILLIE
dialogues.text: You been going out seven years --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So what? You gonna get into that with me too? What does that matter - seven years - what does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How old is Jan?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why even you gotta be like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thirty. She’s thirty --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Thirty. Maybe she wants kids...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hey, fuck that, man. So what? I want kids, too. But what’s the rush? Kathie Lee Gifford had a kid. And she was like forty-five-fucking years old ~~ WILLIE . What’s the meat-cutter got to do with anything... ?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He's this guy. Cuts meat. Comes into the coffee shop where Jan works. She's mentioned him to me before. He’s a character that she tells me about. She tells me about the characters that come into the shop. There’s Millie the manicurist. There’s Jason the carpenter. And then there’s Victor. Victor the meat-cutter...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: So he’s a character?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just a character she would mention. But I started to get a sense --

dialogues.speaker: _. WILLIE
dialogues.text: He was getting more air-time than Millie or Jason --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Exactly. Exactly, you stud. You know.

dialogues.speaker: . WILLIE
dialogues.text: Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You wanna puke? Are you ready to puke? This guy’s 40. Divorced. Has three kids of his own. Arright?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Three kids. So there’s no way she’s getting any sperm from him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. But you know what really creases me? Jan’s a vegetarian. How ‘pout that? The hypocrisy. She’s a vegetarian. He’s a meat-cutter. You know what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What kind of life can she have witha man who stinks of brisket? INT. BIRDMAN/PAUL’S HOUSE - LATER - NIGHT Willie and Paul come in with a 12-pack of Budweiser. Birdman and Sharon are on the couch. Sharon’s sleeping on his lap. Birdman is watching a hockey game on ESPN. ‘

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look who’s here --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: (whispered) Hey --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (whispered) Hey, Birdie -- Birdman gestures to the slumbering Sharon... By way of explanation:

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: (whispered) She doesn’t sleep too good. I/’11 check you out later --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay -- Paul goes upstairs. Willie follows... CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she is surrounded by PHOTOS of her contemporaries - Cindy Elle, Naomi, Linda, Rachel, Helena, Claudia, Niki, Stepha Kate, Cathy, Paulina, etc. For we are in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and the walls are literally covered with MAGAZINE CUT-OU and GLOSSIES of the SUPERMODELS... Paul cracks two beers. Hands one to Willie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: So are you broken up? PAUL . She hates me... Says she wants nothing to do with me ever again --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don’t you worry your pretty little head about it, bro. I got it wired... What about you? You still seeing that chick in New York? The lawyer? '

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tracy. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s up with that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: She's great. But the one thing about her--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL -
dialogues.text: {interrupting) . Ah, they’re all fuckin’ sisters, man, I swear... You piano playing?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: A few lounge things. Nothing steady. Birdman and Sharon still doing okay?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You kidding me? All he thinks about is Darian Smalis. seaaa WILLIE till?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And Sharon knows it. Darian moved back to Knight’s Ridge. With husband and child in tow --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time Sharon looks at Birdie’s face, and sees him thinking of Darian, it's translated into another ugly pound when she looks at herself in the’ mirror. You see her? She looks like one of those kids Sally Struthers feeds paste. They sip their beers. The snow falls outside the window..

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We need models --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: {points to wall) Models. They’re beautiful; they always travel so you don’t have to see ‘em that . much; they make tons of money. Those fuckers that date models have got it made, man. My next girlfriend’s gonna be a model... Paul scarfs at his brew. Willie looks at the wall. From t dunes of St. Tropez, Niki Taylor offers a sympathetic smi

dialogues.speaker: INT, CONWAY HOUSE
dialogues.text: Willie is on the phone in the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) «+. Yes, Mr. Gerron, I’m very interested... Thank you... next Friday's good. This way, I can assess some other considerations and give you a confident answer... No, sir... This is me being decisive... To be truly decisive one has to, uh, weigh the decisions... Great. Thanks -- He hangs up the phone. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie shovels the fresh snow off the driveway... He’s breathing heavy, making more of a mess than he is cleanin

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t shovel much do you? Willie looks up. It is the girl from next door. The 13-year-old who was making the snowman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Just a feeling. Your technique. It’s sloppy. You either live in the city or in a warm climate --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: The city --

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I knew it. You grow up here?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Don’t visit much?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Your mom dead?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Are you a cop?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. My mother’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I knew it. Your dad’s kind of a sad guy. Your brother’s kind of missing that thing... That thing that having a mom gives you... That’s a lonely house you got, you don’t mind me sayin’ -- She has gray-green eyes. Brown hair cut into a page-bob. gn ti Long, thin mbs. Taller than her years. She’s a true heartbreaker-in-training... She chomps on her gum...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Marty --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: As in Martha?  She nods. Big And she bounds

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Iwish. As in Marty. Named for a grandfather I never even knew. Martin. So now I’m Marty. Just Marty. A girl named Marty. It is, I think, the bane of my existence...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thirteen. But I’m an old soul. You don’t come back here too much?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No. My tenth year reunion is next weekend --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Heavy. What's your name? ‘

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Willie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Willie. I like your hair --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks... exaggerated head-bob nods...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You're kinda cool --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I dunno. It’s just a call. You don’t think you are -- ?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No, I think I am.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You are. I think. Maybe not. I gotta go. See ya ‘round -- off into her house. Willie watches after her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. See ya ‘round ~-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A greasy spoon two towns over. In the center island, JAN ~ a fryolator angel, lovely despite the hard years etched into her face - sticks an order slip onto the wheel and s it into the cook’s field of vision... Jan looks to the entrance...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Shit --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: is working his way along the counter... sticking his nose into the CUSTOMERS’ space... . PAUL . You Victor? Are you? Are you Victor? Excuse me, are you Victor? The customers shake their heads. He’s worked his way down where Jan stands, arms crossed...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Victor the meat-cutter. I hit a cow with my plow and I was hoping he could slice me up some steaks. Seems like it'd be a shame to let an entire cow just rot there on the side of the--

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You're not funny, Paul --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What? I’m serious. I had you down for a flank -- Jan ushers him further down the diner...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: And I don't appreciate you burying my driveway eve: time it snows like some kind of drooling, obsessed lunatic with nothing to live for except to torment me because I decided to get on with my life while you decided to destroy yours...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s fair.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What do you want -- ?  PAUL . I just ~- needed to give you this -- He holds out a RING BOX...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's a rump roast. Come on --

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Paul --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can you at least open it? Jan gnaws on a nail... She doesn’t want near that box... Paul turns to an ELDERLY COUPLE watching nearby...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you believe this? The shop's proprietor, 300-pound CHIP comes around to the

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: Paul, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Chip, cut me some slack here --

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: You’re making a spectacle. Take it outside... Jan? Outside... EXT. CHIP’S Paul and Jan huddle in the cold. Most of the counter-customers have turned around to watch them... Paul takes her hand, forces her fingers around the box...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I really don’t think I should --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is beautiful. Just how I always pictured it would be. Love in the afternoon. Harps a-~strumming, angels-a-singing. The whole bit... Jan snaps open the box. Inside is a RING. A big diamond ring... A BROWN diamond ring.  She closes the

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful, Paul. It’s lovely. It’s... bro -- ?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Champagne. It’s champagne. It’s the newest thing. Champagne, not brown...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Champagne. It’s beautiful... box. Gives it back to him...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I can’t take it...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Marry me, Jan.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL -
dialogues.text: No? Just like that? No? -

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Jan. Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You're so selfish...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Selfish? 1I'11 have you know what’s inside that box constitutes some 30 driveways. 30 driveways and maybe two- and-a-half sprinkler systems. Selfish? I think not.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got customers, Paul --~-

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Jan --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Take the fucking ring -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s romantic --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but you’ve sucked the romance out of this entire thing -~

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: This is the desperate act of a desperate man. Only, when faced with losing me, do you decide you want to spend your life with me -- PAUL . What's wrong with that?... I didn’t like the alternative... That usually is how one comes to a decision...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Wrong again, Paul. One comes to a decision based on what one wants, not based on what one doesn’t want. Got it? Now, I got customers. I‘ll see you - She heads back inside to her customers. Leaving Paul with his ring box. INT. BIRDMAN’S TRUCK ~ MOVING - DAY Birdman drives, Willie is beside him...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You know Stinky Womack reopened The Johnson Inn? a WILLIE He did?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: A couple of months ago. Paul and Kev are there. You wanna go by?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long varnished bar with brass "mushroom" taps; moose an deer trophy HEADS on the walls, displaying 12-point baske A roaring fireplace big enough to barbecue a Buick. Cozy.  Willie and Birdman enter. And are immediately fronted by

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY "STINKY" WOMACK, 29
dialogues.text: Stinky is slightly overweight and slightly crazed.

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: What’s up, Birdman? Who's that? Conway? Hey, man! What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Stinky --

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: Christ. Hey. Stinky embraces him... In an aside: They walk to a

dialogues.speaker: STINKY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You wanna lose that "Stinky" stuff, ‘ Will. I’m a bit of a proprietor here ~--

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sti: . What’s up with this? How much call is there for an Inn in The Ridge?

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: We're not gonna run it as an Inn. No beds or nothin’. Just the bar... You know... You got the fireplace... A small menu... Apps...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: "Apps?"

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: He‘s got all the lingo down...

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: Appetizers. We got apps... rear booth where Paul and Kev lush it up --

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: Hey, we got a piano. Maybe later you'll tickle some ivory for us --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe for some free apps he will. Willie and Birdman sit down next to Paul and Kev. They ar quite drunk --

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Willie C.! Welcome home, bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kev -~ Paul is staring drunkenly into space...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: (to Kev) What's got him creased? Kev points to the ring box on the table. Birdman picks it up. Opens it --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What is it? It’s a diamond.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: It’s fuckin’ brown -- ,

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: It's champagne. It's the newest thing -

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: It’s a trend, man. You're 50 uncultured. In diamonds. A trend? Champagne... That’s a nice stone --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Paul's buying the drinks, huh, Kev? Willie picks up the ring...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I heard about this. It’s big in the diamond trade. They been trying to sell these brown stones. Trying to create a market ~-

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: "Champagne." They were calling it "Piss" but they weren’t moving any units. Birdman smacks Paul on the head --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What's with you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you spend for that brown rock?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I dunno. What difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Diamonds are supposed to be colorless. You got out and buy a colored diamond. For a girl you’re not even seeing? You been eating retard sandwiches again -- ? PAUL a I don’t need your shit, Birdie --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I think you do --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think I don’t -~-

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I think you do --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think I don’t --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Kev) I bet this was exactly what it was like when Roosevelt met Churchill for the first time --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You're a schmuck --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look who’s talking, man. Get off your high-horse. You're a human GERALDO episode, for Chrissakes --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Guys --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. Fuck that. Mr. High-horse. You got one broad destroying her marriage and the other one destroying her digestive system... and you just... fuckin’... just ... watch hockey...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You wanna cool it, Klapman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? What are you gonna do, tough guy? Beat me up after Class? Dump my books? This ain’t high school, meatball. The legend is dead.

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Easy, Paul. The legend can still fuck you up two times --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bullshit --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Paul --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Butt out, Conway! Don’t come waltzing back in here and give us your big city bulishit, arright? Just butt out... '

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ loser --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Punk ~-- The four of them sit there, fuming -- An oblivious Stinky comes out of the kitchen, wielding tw trays of potato skins, buffalo wings, fried calamari...

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: (Arthur Godfrey) Free apps! I got free apps!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck off, Stinky --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s just starting to snow... Marty is next door squashin snow piles with her boots... Willie comes out...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Willie Boy...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: It snows here. That’s all it does --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Chillin’.

dialogues.speaker: . WILLIE
dialogues.text: No school?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It’s kind of Saturday --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah -- She stomps on another snow pile...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I like to mash snow, It gives me a tremendous sense of self-satisfaction -- You got a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You’re a dude in flux. If I’m not mistaken, you've come home, back here, to The House Of Loneliness and Tears - to Daddy Downer and Brother Bummer... To come to some sort of decision about life... A life decision, if you will...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You fancy yourself a perceptive little thing, don’t you -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I dunno about “little thing." I’m the tallest girl in my class... Rumor has it (a pediatrician talking to my mom - he didn’t know I could hear him), I may just grow to be 5'10".

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Wow...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I’ll be hot. So? Am I right? A life decision? You got the full-on HAMLET thing going. You know Hamlet? Danish King? “Couldn’t make decisions?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I know Hamlet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About that girlfriend --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. There is one --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: She wants to get married --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sort of --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You don’t --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Not sure --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: She fat? .

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No, she’s quite nice actually --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So marry her --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. I knew I came home for a reason. Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That's it. Tease the jittle kid...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Hey, what do I know? I’m thirteen and suffering from like terminal precociousness? Right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You sort of are -- BIRDMAN/PAUL’S HOUSE - BIRDMAN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Birdman and Sharon under the covers. Making love... Birdm looks to be a million miles away... Sharon watches him... Birdman opens his eyes... Sees her stare... Stops...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be nice - if just once - just once, we could have sex and you'd actually be thinking of me...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tommy, I can’t do this anymore --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: It's not what you think --

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I thought you were gonna get it out of your system... I was willing to ride it out... But this is ridiculous..

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Sharon...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: And you look like such a dweeb... Everyone says 50...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Do they?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: She‘s never gonna leave him... Not for a gardener...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I‘m not a fuckin’ gardener...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: She's never gonna leave him...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: (bad liar) I don’t know what you're talking about -- I haven’t seen her in months... Since we started back up again serious. .

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Forget it, Tommy...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You want to end this?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: That’d be convenient, wouldn’t it? Save you the guilt? Z end it. She gets up, covering herself with the top-sheet. She be to dress...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Here’s the problem: I get asked out, Tommy. All the time. By really cool Men. All my friends say I’m nuts... You guys - Paul, Kev ~ you can’t meet new people. You dig ditches...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Trenches... I dig trenches...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Either way - you don’t come into contact with new people. New, young people. You come into contact with suburban families and construction workers. Once in awhile, if the stars are in your favor, they'll hire a cute girl at the ’ hardware store or the lawn center... Otherwise, forget it. I work in an office. With clients and customers. I like to go out with girlfriends... Go to bars... You guys like to sit at home... You are never-ever gonna meet someone new... And when you do - I hate to tell you this, Tom, but there aren’t that many girls out there looking for Gitch-diggers whose idea of a perfect evening is ESPN and a twelve-pack of Bud cans.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Sharon --

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Maybe the 22-year-olds... But I think even you've outgrown them. So here’s the problem: what do we do? What do we do, when the best days of your life were high school, when you were king of the hill, top cat hot shit... And Darian Smalls was your girlfriend then... So how do I compete? You want that back. You'll never get it - but still... How do I compete with a memory of a way of life that is totally and completely impossible for you to ever have again..? Underwear on, she slides into her skirt...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You're so skinny, Shar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! You have no right. My friends say I’m crazy - the guys who ask me out, they’11 actually take me to restaurants. And care what they look like when they know they’re gonna see me... And talk about the future. Make plans for trips and holidays... And the thing that kills me - the thing that absolutely pisses me off like mad, makes me want to scream and cry and move to another state... Is that I love the ESPN and the twelve-packs. I love the ditch-digger. And I’ve got news for ou, Birdman, I can do a hell of a lot etter. A hell of a lot. The thing is - God help me - I don’t want to... She fixes him with a final wounded look. And then she’s g He looks after her. Then yanks the covers over his head. Hiding out. INT. GINA’S HAIR - CENTER OF TOWN - NIGHT It’s snowing outside the window of this two-chair BEAUTY SALON... Mo’s two fat children run amok... Their mother, LISA, 26, attempts to calm them. Sharon sits in one chair, weeping. Gina sits by her.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: So are you guys broken up? Sharon merely continues to cry...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Are you crying just to avoid us?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Please. Be my friends and don’t make me feel stupid about this for a while...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You must break up with him. You must. You've got to start now, Sharon. The getting over him part. It’s hard, I know... Believe me, I know... She looks to Lisa... Lisa looks to Sharon. Somewhat sadly

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: She’s right -- Sharon merely continues to cry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, after a break-up, you'll have these visions. Visions of you, the fifty-seven-year- old, unmarried you: you're a librarian; hair in a bun; otato sack dresses; the neighborhood ids call you "The Spinster." And every night you go to your little room, heat up a can of soup-for-one and lament over the cobwebs crowding your womb...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yecch... !

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: But these visions fade away... Really... It takes time. But you will get over him. It'll take two years. You'll be 29... It would be better if you were younger. If you were, say, 24 now, you'd be 26 when you got over him... But we don’t get to choose these things...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: They choose us...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That’s not exactly ancient...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: That’s not exactly 30...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Which is good...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Which is very good...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: You_can say what you want - and I admit it looks bad - but no one knows what it’s like when it’s just the two of us... You know, behind closed doors...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Okay. That's fair. So how is it?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Not so good lately...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: The man can’t commit. The man can’t commit. The man can’t commit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come every time a relationship doesn’t work out, we say it’s cos can’t commit. Shouldn’t we shoulder some of the responsibility? Her friends look stunned. Lisa slaps a hand over her mouth... Gina crosses herseif...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: That’s just the grief talking... That’s not you...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That's not Sharon Cassidy...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: It’s just a girl - a grief-stricken girl - who happens to look like Sharon Cassidy.. .

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I’m still not sure if they’re broken up.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Oh, they’re broken up all right. Shar? Sharon looks up from between her tears...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tommy’ 65 birthday is next week. Maybe I’1l have a surprise party for him --

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Shar --

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Will you guys help me organize it? Gina and Lisa. A look.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Will you ~- ? Gina shakes her head. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Sure, Sharon --

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Whatever you want... EXT. dJAN’S DUPLEX - LATER - NIGHT Paul and Elle Macpherson are parked in his truck in front Jan’s... He slides a CD into the deck... Black Sabbath. "Paranoid" ("Finished with my woman/cos she couldn't hel with my mind... ") He puts out his cigarette and lowers the plow -- -- once again making the apartment’s driveway impassable. EXT. MO’'S HOUSE ~ DAY A good-sized split-level. Shannon and Michael Jr. chase a neighbor’s DOG around the snow... INT. MO’S HOUSE Willie and Mo sip their coffee at the table... Lisa shows Willie a framed PHOTO of Lisa and the kids on a boat in a eae

dialogues.text: He deserved to get thrashed like that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No, but... This does present something of a moral dilemma -- Paul and Mo stare at him like he's nuts... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Arright. Fuck it. Let’s lynch the bastard -- EXT. DARIAN’S HOUSE - NIGHT The snow is heavier now. Paul pulls the truck up into the long Tudor driveway we OPENED with...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: We got a plan? But Mo is out of the truck and racing up the drive...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: No plan. Mo is pounding on the front door... INT. DARIAN’S HOUSE Steve, in boxers, t-shirt and tube socks, glances out the window... He picks up his cordless PHONE... dials a numbe

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey. How far are you guys? Yeah. You wanna turn arount and come back? I got

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: STEVEN (cont‘’d) company... Cool beans, dude... EXT. DARIAN’S HOUSE Willie and Paul have joined Mo at the door --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m getting wicked "villagers outside Frankenstein’s castle" vibes - how bout you, guys -- ? Before they can respond, Steve has opened the door, still boxers and tee --

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Can I help you, guys? Mo rips open the storm door and yanks Steve outside, toss him into a nearby snowbank... :

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this? Mo is apoplectic, wailing, enraged --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You mess with my friends, you mess with me! You beat-up my friends, you beat-up me! You take what’s mine, you take what’s yours! You go to the fountain, you drink, you don’t drink... ‘1 Willie shoots Paul a look. Paul shrugs. Don’t ask me...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talk-- But Mo is on him, shoving Steve’s head into the snow --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Don’t you talk back to me, little man!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Easy, Mo -- HEADLIGHTS coming up the long drive... A BMW, loaded with lineman... Steve having called them on their cellular...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: The cavalry has arrived. Assholes -- Steve, shivering, gets to his feet... Mo and Paul look to oncoming auto...  oéN

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s all bad -- Paul turns to look at Willie. But Willie is nowhere to be oun --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Will -- 7? The BMW roars up to the house... Steve wears the most. sanctimonious of grins... Paul looks scared... Even Mo is sobered considerably... The Beemer comes to a stop... But before the frat~boys ca get out of their car, they are BLINDED BY LIGHTS -~ -- and an ENGINE sings to life... It is Paul’s TRUCK - Willie at the wheel... He raises the PLOW... Puts the car into gear... ‘ And heads straight for the BMW -- ! The frat boys SCREAM. Willie barrels the truck right at t

dialogues.speaker: KEE-RUNCH
dialogues.text: The plow hits the driver’s side of the car... The guys in shriek as the car is PUSHED several feet and WEDGED UP against the SNOWBANK on the passenger side... Making it impossible to get out... Paul howls... Mo giggles... Steve is horrified... Willie shuts off the engine... Hops from the truck...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You rock, Johnny... They high-five... Mo returns his attention to Steve...

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Now, where were we, shithead? Mo grabs the scruffs of Steve’s tee-shirt and is about to a big fist on him, when --

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy -- ? She is at the door... In her nightie... Looking for all t world like Little Cindy Lou Who from THE GRINCH...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What is she doing here?  113.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We had a sitter. I sent her home.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Daddy? What -- ? Kristen looks at Mo - the man hurting her daddy - with bi blue wounded eyes... Mo looks at Steve...

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to save my family here, man "-- Mo couldn't be more ashamed... He looks at his friends... Looks back at the little girl... He releases Steve... Sig And walks back to the pick-up... Willie and Paul watch him go. Paul turns to Steve...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Stay away from us, Stevie Boy. Just stay away forever... And they go back to the truck... Steve looks at Kristen..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Go inside, honey. Everything’s okay -- Willie and Paul climb into the truck. The frat-guys screa on from the Bi Paul backs up the pick-up... freeing the Griver’ s side o car. The frat guys explode out... But Paul is already far down the driveway... They chase after it, but it’s slippery and they give up.. At the foot of the driveway, the truck passes Darian Smal in her Jeep, returning from the reunion... She rolls down window, her face a question mark. But they don’t even giv her the benefit of a roll-down. They just drive off... She watches them leave her home, completely puzzled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upscale joint. Yuppies and endive. Sharon sits at a two-top with a DATE - (perhaps the man from her office wh smiled at her). Late-30s, with an attractive, why-is~he- still-single? look about him... Gina enters the restaurant, a little breathless. Scours. She sees Sharon and her date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- SHARON . What are you doing here, Gina -- ?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: We have a little-- (to the date) Gina Barrisano --

dialogues.speaker: DATE
dialogues.text: Brian Donnelly... They shake hands... Gina studies BRIAN... She likes what sees...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Gina -- ?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: God, this is killing me... Brian, you’re an inch from perfect. Sharon’s the best. Do not let what will soon occur, in any way prevent you from allowing this relationship to evolve. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Gina -- !

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Shit. Okay. Birdman got himself all beat-up. Steve Rossmore. He's at Grover... Without a moment’s hesitation, Sharon is out of her chair

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Brian... I’ve got to go...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: (to Brian) Told ya --

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Can I give you guys a lift?

dialogues.speaker: . SHARON
dialogues.text: We’re fine... Let’s go, Gina... Sharon heads for the door... Gina lags behind...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Think of this as a glitch. A momentary lapse of reason, if you will...  Sharon calls to her from the exit...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Gina -- !

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Gotta run --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kev, Tracy and Lisa wait... Willie, Paul and Mo come in...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: They took him a while ago. We haven't heard anything -- Willie sits down next to Tracy... She takes his hand...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Did you guys do macho things? Willie shrugs. He watches

dialogues.speaker: MO AND LISA
dialogues.text: down the hall a bit.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Did you call Annie? Teil her we'd be date -- ?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yes. I told her she could sleep over.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: That was good --

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You okay? Beat. Mo nods. Looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Lis --

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Don’t. It’s cool -- She puts her arms around him. He hugs her. Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go -- They look up. Stinky is coming down the corridor. Everyone gets up and encircles him --

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: He's going to be okay. He’s got a concussion, two broken ribs... Fractured wrist. And he took thirty stitches --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: But he’s gonna be okay -- ?

dialogues.speaker: STINKY
dialogues.text: He’s gonna be fine -- {to Kev) He said to tell you it’s snowing and you should clear the lots -- .

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: I’m on it --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tell him I’11 be by tomorrow to say goodbye --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to go back to New York with Tracy --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just like that --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: dust like that. EXT. dJAN’S DUPLEX - LATER ~ NIGHT Once again, Paul sits across the street in his truck. Watching the apartment and smoking. Elle Macpherson whimp beside him. Paul stamps out his cigarette. He slides a disc in the de A sad song. John Cougar’s “Ain't Even Done With The Night Paul begins to cry to the tune, which will play throughou the remaining scenes of this evening... INT. CONWAY HOUSE - WILLIE’'S ROOM - LATER - NIGHT Tracy is in bed. Willie comes to tuck her in.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: The couch is okay -- ?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Sorry about the night.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I had fun. It’s lively around here ~~ (beat) How come you're coming back with me?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno. I want to. J don’t think I’m going to take that sales job...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I don’t think you should...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t... ?

dialogues.speaker: . TRACY
dialogues.text: Piano players are sexy. Salesmen are... uncles...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Uncles aren’t sexy...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Not usually... Beat. She pulls him to her... Into a long kiss... They be to make love... Willie stops it for:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: This is too weird. This is my boyhood bedroom --

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You never had sex in here?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Not with another person -- She laughs. They kiss. Still the Cougar song plays: "Well it’s time to go home/And I ain’t even done with the night INT. BIRDMAN’S ROOM - NIGHT Sharon sits by Birdman’s bed... He's awake but sluggish..

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Are you in a lot of pain -- ?  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I'm arright. You look nice...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: I came from a date -~-

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: A good guy?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: He's okay...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Where’d you go?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Carlotti’s...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I haven’t been there in years... You eat?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: A salad.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: A salad. -

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: It's weird...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I’m laying here... And I’m wondering how I got to here... I don’t mean this thing with Rossmore; this hospital... I mean, in general... How I got to here... How I’m really not anything like what I hoped I'd be... I’m not even close to the guy I thought I'd be... It kinda OWS...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Tommy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I gotta tell you - when I think about it... When I imagine it... That guy... Close to that guy... There’s, uh... This girl next to him... With him... And she... I dunno... She looks sorta like you...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: "Sorta?"

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Exactly. Exactly sorta. Tears stand in Birdman’s eyes...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Wow. Must be the medication...

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Then let's get more of it... They smile...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Look everybody - my baby’s beside me... She kisses his forehead... Fixes his blankets.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: All good... That’s all good... EXT. JAN’S DUPLEX - NIGHT CONTINUE MUSIC. Paul is really weeping now. An exaggerate blubber. He starts up the truck. We’re sure he’s going to barricade her in again. But this time he plows the driveway. Plows it clean... Crying and singing all the while... From an upstairs window, Jan watches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early the next morning. Willie walks from the parking lot the entrance... He sees Gina, waiting out front, sitting wheelchair, something of a stupor...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  . GINA . . I figured out the fourth biggest lie --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You know ~ there's "The Check Is In The Mail." "I Love You." "I Won't Come In Your--

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I know. So what’s number four?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: "No, no, really... I love cats... "7 Willie frowns... Gina shrugs...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'll... see ya ‘round, Gina -- He walks into the hospital... Gina doesn’t even notice he gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie walks down the hall. Kev, in his work clothes, is sprawled out on two chairs in the waiting room. He snores away. INT. BIRDMAN’S ROOM Sharon has pulled a chair up to Birdman’s bed. She is asleep, her head resting on his belly.. Willie comes in... Birdman opens his puffy eyes... He loo awful.. He manages a weak smile... They whisper their exchange s0 as not to wake her --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I ran into Gina downstairs. I think she’s having some kind of rage- withdrawal... You look excellent --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: You guys trashed Rossmore?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Nah. Put the fear of God in him, that’s all. He sorta turned out to be a crispy turd, didn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: He had cause to be creased --  Beat. Willie gestures to Sharon --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How's she doing -- ?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: She's okay -- WILLIE . She rocks, bro. You gonna fuck it up?

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure. She’s one of the good ones. Don’t we always manage to fuck up the good ones... ?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I know I’ve been fairly successful at it... Take care, Birdman...

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Come back and visit more often -- Sharon stirs. Wakes. Sees Willie --

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (to Birdman) You okay? Hi -- Birdman nods. Then: A SQUEAL! And Shannon and Michael, dr., Mo’s kids, come tearing into the hospital room, runn around crazy --

dialogues.speaker: BIRDMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Later, guys -- INT. HOSPITAL - OUTSIDE BIRDMAN’S ROOM Willie comes out. Mo carries a bouquet of BALLOONS.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How you feeling today, tough guy?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Like hell... You’re leaving?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Say goodbye to Lisa --

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Iwill. Say goodbye to Tracy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: You figure that shit out?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: It changes from minute to minute, man. Indecision is a disease and I got a virulent strain -- (re: Kev) When he wakes up, tell ‘em I said goodbye... There's a CRASH from Birdman’s room... And Birdman WAILS:

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I better get in there --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Later, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie puts their luggage in the trunk of the Saab. He lo at Marty’s house, but there’s no one around... Pete and Dougie Conway hug Tracy goodbye... They look lik they’re going to cry. Paul pulls up in his pick-up...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Word is Jan and Victor are engaged --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Jeez... How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That chick drains me, man. They're ail sisters. Everyone of ‘em. Sisters --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yo, Willie Boy -~ ? Willie turns. Marty is there, in her yard...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You outta here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (re: Tracy) She is a honey-limbed lovely --~

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- Tracy comes down the walkway...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Tracy, this is Marty... Marty, Tracy..:

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you -- Beat. Willie studies them, side by side...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You’re very pretty --

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Thank you. You are, too -- (beat; to Willie) We should get going, hon...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Right -- - Willie hugs Paul ~-

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So long, Chief -- Willie walks over to Marty and gives her a kiss on the ch Marty blushes. Willie probably does too --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Bye, Marty --

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Later, Pooh -- Paul and Marty lean back against the truck watching Willi and Tracy go around to the Saab --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ya‘ll come back now, y’here? We'll be right where you left us. Nothing changes in The Ridge but the seasons --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty. As in "Martha?"

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: She wishes. As in "Martin." Named for a grandfather she never even knew... Tracy looks at him a little odd...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You okay? Willie looks at her. Considers. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think I am...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Good. Let’s go -- They make for the highway -- Up ahead, Birdman’s PICK-UP/PLOW is coming at them, Kev a the wheel... Kev slows... sticks his head out the window:

dialogues.speaker: KEV
dialogues.text: Stay cool, Willie C.! Stay forever cool! Willie gives him the thumbs-up and they are gone... Kev watches them go... He cracks a beer... Pours it into "KRISTEN" mug... He notices something on his windshield.. sticks his hand out the window... It’s starting to snow...

dialogues.speaker: KEV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Shit. And we play that Gin Blossoms song we opened with... As K puts the truck into drive. Heading off... «».the truck soon lost to us in the gently falling snow. The End
